div.p:
I must trouble you to read the
enclosed letters from Hunter to
me and my last to him -
-about Harry and Lucy - Letter No. 1 - and 2 will show you that I took every precaution to assure myself that Hunter was not a loser by my chang ing the title of H & L - I have not kept any copies of my letters but I daresay Hunter has my letter of Feb 1826 in whh I offered then to deduct from the copy right whatever he after the promised years experience shd find or think he had lost by the book - His own answer Feb 23d 1826 - declines accepting my
proffered deduction & only
accepts my offer of delaying
payment -
Dec.r 1826 - he again asks me to
delay the promised payment
for another year - but without
even hinting that he had lost
by the publication - I acceded
to the delay - & told him (of course)
that I would not take the int
which he offered -

I make no doubt that
his statements of accounts are
true - but I think his losses
may in great measure arise
from his own mismanagement
for which I am not answerable.
- I hope my dear Francis you
will approve of my letter to
him & of my not making
any hesitation in acceding
to his proposal though I certainly
do not feel that I am bound
either by promise or honor
to accede to it -
I leave the letter in your
hands to deliver or not as you
think proper - If you see any
thing in it that you as my friend
wish altered I am sure you
will tell me so -
Fortunately - or I may say prudently
I have not pledged or spent any
part of this 100 £- though I own
I depend on its payment as
securely the ensuing Jan.y
January as
if it had been in bank - I had
intended to have had the plea-
sure pleasure of giving it and that is all
I lose in reality -

When Doctor Brewster was
here a few months ago he kindly
urged me to let him and a
society of literary men at
Edin
burgh Edinburgh
publish any future
book for me - he assured me
that as they employ printers
without the middleman called
a publisher they find they can
afford to give more copyright
than is usually given by publishers
- When I told him what Hunter
was to give me for H & L - he
said we could give you a third
more - When he spoke of a future
publication book which I had told him
I was thinking of beginning to
write he urged me to consider
my own interest I replied that
I felt myself engaged to Hunter
and that whether engaged or
not I never would quit him
as long as he should continue
to wish to publish for me -

But what he has now written
to me I think alters the case -
and as he assures me that he
is no gainer by my publications
do you not think I am now
right in telling him as I do in
my letter that all accounts are
closed between us? -

You perceive that I have
not hinted to him anything
of my intention to write a new
work because I did not think
it handsome to do so on his
account or prudent on mine
- but I am anxious to know
your opinion on this point for my
own satisfaction - I must
add my dear Francis for your satisfaction
that whatever little present mortification
I may feel in hearing that the sale of
Harry & Lucy is so slow, is nothing in compar-
ison comparison with the heartfelt pleasure I have in
knowing that those whom I consider as the
best judges approve of the book & think it wor-
-thy worthy of the first part of H & L - I feel that the
infinite pains which you & my dear Honora
and Fanny & William bestowed upon it have
not been thrown away - It has gained far more
credit in the literary world than I or I dare
say than you ever expected - But it was not
written either for fame or money - The object I had
in view has been fully & to me delightfully ac-
complished accomplished - I would go over again all the
labor to have this feeling; and what is more -
I would willingly again accept from you
my dear friend all your labor & time &
anxiety - I cannot more strongly express
the value of my self-satisfaction - a feeling
I hope distinct from either pride or vanity
div.closer:
I am most gratefully & affectionately
Your obliged
Maria Edgeworth
Captn. BeaufortR N.
